intro.txt: this is the life you get:
a husband and wife, 1.5 kids, a dog. white picket fence and big green yard.

body.txt: i thought a lot about love when i was young
imaginary men who'd sweep me off my feet
then, we'd ride off into the sunset: happily ever after
and then i meet the actual love of my life
shortly thereafter, two brides take to the altar
two brides picture a future together
a wife and wife, 1.5 kids, a dog. white picket fence and big green yard.
we live in a duplex with six other people
we convince our roommates to let us get a dog
box checked, we look to the future
1.5 kids, white picket fence, big green yard
thousands of dollars in debt
we find a new small room to squeeze into, pressed flush together, no room to breathe but the cycle of breath from our lungs
we work, work, work. scroll zillow on the weekends. plot savings plans
and then the world ends
maga and pandemic and wildfire. the sky turns orange three times in 1.5 years
clung fast to one another, we make it ashore
1.5 kids, white picket fence, big green yard
1.5 kids, white picket fence, (we don't need a big yard, really)
my wife would be the one to carry
my wife approaches the far edge of the age range when it is safe
can i do it? can i do it? can i do it?
(she tells me i dont have to; there's always adoption)
1.5 kids, white picket fence
thousands in debt become tens of thousands. college, baby
and the sky goes orange once more; he is back in office
to raise a child in this world
who could raise a child in this world?
1.5 kids, white picket fence
1.5 kids, (a place where we are safe, a place to call our own)
i list the things i'd need to carry our child
get fit, get therapy, get a career, get a home
our dog's face is slowly turning white
one december, i become unburdened
dr. daniel jacobs from the gender confirmation center removes 7 pounds and 2 ounces of flesh from my chest
with it goes my back pain and dysphoria
with it goes the possibility to ever nurse our child
can i do it?
she knows i don't want to; she doesn't want me to, either
adoption is an option now, but who knows?
and is adoption even ethical?
can i do it?
can i do it?
can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i do it? can i
i can't
i can't do it
but she would make such an excellent mother
i ask her, "what if we never have kids?"
guilt lives in the hollow of my throat. i could cry
she shrugs, smiles
"we'll have lots of dogs"
she takes my hand and turns back to the sunrise
a wife and wife, lots of dogs. somewhere safe that's ours.
our friends and two cats, someday
her parents and my parents and my grandma and her brothers and my siblings
her nieces and nephews and niblings. all of our cousins by blood and by starlight
an open door to somewhere warm
and her and me
and the rest of our lives
